node.title: ‘Writing With Fire’ Review: Speaking Truth to Power
node.alt: Suneeta, a reporter in the documentary “Writing With Fire.”
node.description: This rousing documentary follows the reporters of India’s only all-women news outlet as they pivot to digital journalism while battling personal and political challenges.
node.content: ["Several times in the documentary \u201cWriting With Fire,\u201d we see women reporters standing alone in a crowd of men \u2014 cops, miners, political rallyists \u2014 asking gentle but firm questions. The women\u2019s grit in the face of palpable hostility is impressive, and it becomes more so when you learn that they\u2019re in Uttar Pradesh, an Indian province known for crimes against women, and that they are Dalits, or members of the country\u2019s so-called untouchable caste.", "These are the reporters of Khabar Lahariya, India\u2019s only women-led newspaper. In \u201cWriting With Fire,\u201d the directors Rintu Thomas and Sushmit Ghosh follow the outlet\u2019s pivot to digital coverage in the lead-up to the general election in 2019. Many of the women have never used smartphones or cameras, and for much of the film, the reporters train each other and exchange feedback in heartening displays of sororal solidarity.", "Scenes from the reporters\u2019 home lives emphasize how trivial these technical challenges seem compared to domestic ones. Meera, a veteran, tough-as-a-nut journalist, was married at 14 and earned three degrees while raising her children; the feisty Suneeta cannot get married because her parents can\u2019t afford the dowries charged by men who would allow her to work.", "But Thomas and Ghosh focus on arcs of resistance rather than repression, tracing how, as Khabar Lahariya\u2019s YouTube channel rapidly gains followers, its stories achieve real results: a neglected town receives medical attention; a rapist is prosecuted. If the film\u2019s brisk telling sometimes presents these victories as too easily won, it\u2019s a necessary corrective to the skepticism the women still face (\u201cThey\u2019re destined to fail,\u201d Meera\u2019s husband scoffs).", "And at a time when the profession faces increasing dangers in India, the film\u2019s faith in the powers of grassroots journalism is nothing short of galvanizing."]
